text:
If I may,,,A few other data points. 
I looked images created on another of my personal(consumer) devices that was
Windows 10 Pro up to March 2023 then updated to Win11 Pro via Windows Update. 
The device’s WinRE partition full size was 1 GB(1024 MB) 
The WinRE partition’s ***used space** on that 1 GB WinRE partition for each
point in time are: 
Win 10 Pro March 2023 – 602 MB 
Win 11 Pro March 2023 – 675 MB (a few days after upgrading from Win10 Pro to
Win11 Pro) 
Win11 Pro June 2023 – 729 MB (the month that MSFT started including WinRE in
cumulative updates) 
Win 11 Pro Nov 2023 – 818 MB 
Win 11 Pro Jan 2024 – 829 MB (after installing Jan. 2024 updates; an increase
of 11 MB since Nov. 2023) 
Not entirely representative of the above but here is one additional data point
to show the WinRE partition’s growth pattern over time from a longer
perspective. 
* I created an image on this same device shortly after purchase in October 2017
 – The Win10 Pro’s Windows Recovery partition used space at that time was 323
 MB.
 * In 6.25 yrs(Oct ’17 to Jan ’24) it increased by 506 MB
 * In 5.5 yrs(Oct ’17 to Mar ’23) it increased by 279 MB
 * In 10 months(Mar ’23 to Jan ’24) it increased by 227 MB 
i.e. The WinRE partition has been increasing in size for some time. 
I’m at the point of changing my recommendation of 1 GB size for the Recovery
Partition when clean installing Windows 10 or Windows 11(Pro or Home). 
* 2 GB might be appropriate going forward to avoid carving out space/shrinking
 the Windows(Boot) partition for the constantly growing WinRE partition. 
A question might be – will we need a 3 GB WinRE partition before Windows 11
reaches EOL? ! 
Maybe MSFT will eventually update this article to reflect what is really needed
in the long term, not just the initial deployment of Win10 or Win11. 
<

[https://can01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Flearn.microsoft.com%2Fen-us%2Fwindows-hardware%2Fmanufacture%2Fdesktop%2Fconfigure-uefigpt-based-hard-drive-partitions%3Fview%3Dwindows-11&data=05%7C02%7Cemail_ingestion%40bighatgroup.com%7C6556d4d63ca7446be3f208dc13455666%7C5a01497e1bcb4711b6e6d24f4ab00393%7C0%7C0%7C638406435729144325%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=e0NJfyExaU1uuKbo51Sd0ktTj2j9Hp4Hcg%2FOv3GSZfA%3D&reserved=0]> 
“This partition must be at least 300 MB. 
The Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) tools require additional free
space: 
•             A minimum of 100 MB is required but 250 MB is recommended, to
accommodate future updates, especially with custom partition layouts. 
When calculating free space, note: 
•             The recovery image, winre.wim, is typically between 500-700MB,
depending on what drivers, languages, and customizations you add. 
•             The file system itself can take up additional space. For example,
NTFS may reserve 5-15MB or more on a 750MB partition.” 
Note: The size for the WinRE partition shown in the above article’s script
samples for Windows PE and Diskpart(CreatePartitions-UEFI.txt) = 500 MB.
